function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Poor urban communities are most vulnerable to vector-borne diseases (VBDs) due to lack of infrastructure and poor living conditions.","Impact":"Increased transmission of VBDs and higher risk of outbreaks, impacting the health and well-being of the community.","Mitigation":"Improvement of urban infrastructure, access to clean water, waste management, and better housing conditions.","Technologies":"Urban planning tools, water purification systems, waste management technologies, and housing infrastructure innovations.","People":"Poor urban communities in low-and middle-income countries.","Owner":"Local governments, UN-Habitat, community organizations."},{"Description":"Lack of community participation in disease control efforts reduces the effectiveness of preventative measures and policies.","Impact":"Higher prevalence of VBDs and increased risk of outbreaks due to lack of community support and cooperation.","Mitigation":"Community engagement and outreach programs to involve local residents in disease control efforts and policy development.","Technologies":"Community engagement platforms, educational programs, and communication tools.","People":"Local residents in urban communities at risk of VBDs.","Owner":"Local governments, community organizations, global health agencies."},{"Description":"Lack of integration of health priorities in sustainable development goals could lead to neglect of VBD risks in urban environments.","Impact":"Inadequate allocation of resources and attention to urban VBD risks, resulting in continued vulnerability and lack of preparedness for outbreaks.","Mitigation":"Incorporation of health indicators and targets into the sustainable development agenda, emphasizing the link between health and sustainable development.","Technologies":"Data analytics and monitoring tools to track health indicators and outcomes, policy development platforms for sustainable development goals.","People":"Global policymakers, urban planners, health professionals.","Owner":"Global health agencies, UN agencies, policymakers."}]}
